channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine and Japan Among Latest Members of U.N. Security Council
item.description: The two countries, along with Egypt, Senegal and Uruguay, won two-year seats alongside the Council’s permanent members, which include Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Syrian Forces and Russian Jets Attack Rebel-Held Towns
item.description: The new offensive aims to break rebel control of a highway between two major cities, according to Syrian state media and antigovernment activists.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Smoke is seen over Jobar, Syria, after reports of a bombing campaign by the Syrian government on rebel positions.

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Great British Immigration Debate
item.description: A loss for England in rugby and the victory of a woman of Bangladeshi descent on “The Great British Bake Off” contribute to a debate about immigrants and what it means to be British.
item.category: The Great British Bake Off (TV Program)
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Nadiya Jamir Hussain after winning “The Great British Bake Off.” For some, she offered testimony to the notion that immigrants enrich the nation’s cultural loam.

item.title: 2 Lockerbie Bombing Suspects, Libyans, Sought by U.S. and Scotland
item.description: Prosecutors have asked the Libyan government for help tracking down two Libyans in connection with the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Obama Announces Halt of U.S. Troop Withdrawal in Afghanistan
item.description: Under the revised plans, the current force will stay in place through most of 2016 before dropping to about 5,500 at the end of next year or in early 2017.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: American Army soldiers at a base in the Khogyani district of Afghanistan in August.

item.title: Migrant Crisis Leads to Calls for Tighter Borders in Europe
item.description: Gathering in Brussels, European leaders also endorsed a push to get Turkey to control the flow of Syrians and others before they can reach Europe.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Oscar Pistorius to Leave Prison for House Arrest
item.description: The Paralympic gold medalist who was found guilty in the killing of his girlfriend will leave prison after serving about one year of his five-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius leaving court in Pretoria, South Africa, last year, after he was found guilty of culpable homicide.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: American Publishers Take a Stand Against Censorship in China
item.description: Their pledge is a response to a report released in May by the PEN American Center that showed how the translated works of foreign authors are sometimes published with unauthorized excisions.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at a rally against Chinese censorship in front of the New York Public Library ahead of a BookExpo America event in May. A large delegation of publishers from China attended the trade gathering as guests of honor.

item.title: Graffiti on ‘Homeland,’ Unnoticed by Producers, Calls Show Racist
item.description: Three artists took credit, saying it was a protest of false and misleading stereotypes in the series, which has been criticized for its portrayals of Muslims.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and MONA BOSHNAQ
item.media:description: “ ‘Homeland’ is racist,” read graffiti shown on the television program.

item.title: Europe’s Refugee Crisis: What Readers Want to Know
item.description: Readers inquire about the women who remain at home in places like Syria, and wonder if the wave of migration will truly bolster the European economy.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Discarded life vests and the remnants of rubber rafts on the Greek island of Lesbos last month, left behind by scores of migrants and refugees.

item.title: France in Stalemate With Vatican Over Nomination of Envoy Said to Be Gay
item.description: Nine months after Paris put forward Laurent Stefanini as its nominee, the Holy See still has not said whether it would accept his credentials. Nor has it explained the delay.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Competitive Bridge Is Not a Sport, a British Court Rules
item.description: The decision dealt a blow to players seeking to obtain official recognition and government financing to teach the game in schools and encourage students to take it up.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Mayor de Blasio, on Israel Trip, Plans Visit With Palestinians
item.description: Mr. de Blasio considered visiting the West Bank, but that trip is unlikely in part because of recent Israeli-Palestinian violence.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York will be visiting the Middle East this week.

item.title: Open Source: Israel Accuses Abbas of Lying About Wounded Boy in Video
item.description: Many misconceptions have surrounded footage that showed a Palestinian boy bleeding profusely on an East Jerusalem street.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority held up an image of Ahmad Manasra, 13, during an address televised Wednesday night.

item.title: Zoo’s Public Dissection of Lion Makes Denmark Again a Target of Outrage
item.description: The move comes a year after a zoo in Copenhagen generated global outrage when it killed a healthy giraffe, before dissecting him and feeding him to lions.
item.category: European Assn of Zoos and Aquaria
People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The corpse of a lion being prepared before a public dissection in the Odense Zoo in Denmark on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Jinping’s Speech on the Arts Is Released, One Year Later
item.description: A year after the Chinese president made a landmark address on artists’ role in society, Xinhua, the state news agency, released the transcript in full.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Obama to Announce Halt of U.S. Troop Withdrawal in Afghanistan
item.description: Under the revised plans, the current force will stay in place through most of 2016 before dropping to about 5,500 at the end of next year or in early 2017, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: American Army soldiers at a base in the Khogyani district of Afghanistan in August.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Officers Are Charged in Beating of Protester
item.description: The officers are accused of beating Ken Tsang, a participant in protests last year that called for electoral changes, during a clash that was caught on video.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Ken Tsang talked to reporters in the spot where he said he was beaten by police officers during pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong last year.

item.title: U.S. Exploring Deal to Limit Pakistan’s Nuclear Arsenal
item.description: Outside experts familiar with the talks expressed doubt that Pakistan was willing to curb what it regards as its only real defense against India.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Kathmandu Journal: Waits Stretch for Days as Nepal Confronts Fuel Shortage
item.description: Thousands lined up after the government briefly eased a ban on sales to private vehicles imposed in the face of constitutional protests and a dispute with India.
item.dc:creator: DONATELLA LORCH
item.media:description: Lining up for fuel at a gas station in Kathmandu, Nepal, this week.
